summary.p: The Query class is the most important class in NQuery. This class allows you to execute a SELECT query against a DataContext.

section.title: Syntax
section.p: The syntax is based on SQL-92 (with some extensions from SQL-99) For details see SELECT Syntax.

section.title: Execution Methods
section.p: For your convenience the Query class provides different methods for query execution which are summarized in the table below.

tr.td: Executes the query and returns the result as DataTable.
Executes the query and returns the first column of the first row.
Compiles the query but does not actually execute it. This method retuns an empty DataTable in which all column definitions are set as if the query would have been executed.

Executes the query and returns the result as QueryDataReader. For query results with large amounts of data this method is faster than ExecuteDataTable because the data is not fully loaded in-memory but returned through a light weight, forward-only cursor.

Compiles the query but does not actually execute it. This method retuns an QueryDataReader that will not return any data but has all column definitions set as if the query would have been executed. This method is equivalent to ExecuteSchemaDataTable.
